clusters.title: Remains of last Israeli held in Gaza after 7 October 2023 returned
clusters.neutral_headline: Remains of last Israeli held in Gaza after 7 October 2023 returned

items.title: Remains of last Israeli held in Gaza after 7 October 2023 returned
items.standfirst: Return of police sergeant Ran Gvili’s body should pave way for progress on second phase of Trump ceasefire planThe remains of the Israeli police sergeant Ran Gvili, who was killed fighting Hamas-led militants on 7 October 2023, have been returned to Israel.Militants took Gvili’s body to Gaza to use as a bargaining chip. He was the last of 251 people captured that day still held in the territory. Continue reading...
items.content: Return of police sergeant Ran Gvili’s body should pave way for progress on second phase of Trump ceasefire planThe remains of the Israeli police sergeant Ran Gvili, who was killed fighting Hamas-led militants on 7 October 2023, have been returned to Israel.Militants took Gvili’s body to Gaza to use as a bargaining chip. He was the last of 251 people captured that day still held in the territory. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel says it has retrieved remains of final Gaza hostage
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called Ran Gvili’s return "an extraordinary achievement".
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called Ran Gvili’s return "an extraordinary achievement".

items.title: Israel says remains of last hostage recovered from Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel's military says the remains of Ran Gvili, the last person whose body was taken hostage into Gaza, have been recovered.
items.content: Israel's military says the remains of Ran Gvili, the last person whose body was taken hostage into Gaza, have been recovered.

items.title: Israel has recovered the final hostage remains from Gaza
items.standfirst: The Israeli military says the body of Ran Gvili, a 24-year-old special forces policeman killed while fighting Hamas militants on Oct. 7, 2023, has been found.
items.content: The Israeli military says the body of Ran Gvili, a 24-year-old special forces policeman killed while fighting Hamas militants on Oct. 7, 2023, has been found.(Image credit: Ilia Yefimovich)

items.title: Israel retrieves remains of last Gaza hostage, Netanyahu says
items.standfirst: Israel on Monday retrieved ⁠the remains of Ran Gvili, the last remaining hostage held in Gaza, fulfilling a key condition of ‍the initial phase of US President Donald Trump's ​plan to end the Gaza war. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hailed an "incredible achievement" for the Israeli military and its people.
items.content: Israel on Monday retrieved ⁠the remains of Ran Gvili, the last remaining hostage held in Gaza, fulfilling a key condition of ‍the initial phase of US President Donald Trump's ​plan to end the Gaza war. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hailed an "incredible achievement" for the Israeli military and its people.

items.title: Remains of last Israeli hostage found in Gaza, paving way for next phase of ceasefire
items.standfirst: The remains of the last hostage held in Gaza have been identified, the Israeli military said Monday, ending a more than two-year saga for captives' families in Israel — and paving the way for the second phase of the ceasefire in the war-torn enclave.
items.content: The remains of the last hostage held in Gaza have been identified, the Israeli military said Monday, ending a more than two-year saga for captives' families in Israel — and paving the way for the second phase of the ceasefire in the war-torn enclave.

items.title: Remains of last Israeli captive Ran Gvili recovered from Gaza, says Israel
items.standfirst: Retrieval of Gvili's body could pave the way for next phase of the ceasefire, including reopening the Rafah crossing.
items.content: Retrieval of Gvili's body could pave the way for next phase of the ceasefire, including reopening the Rafah crossing.

items.title: Remains of last Israeli hostage found in Gaza
items.standfirst: The remains of the last Israeli hostage in Gaza have been found.
items.content: The remains of the last Israeli hostage in Gaza have been found.

items.title: Gaza’s Rafah crossing to reopen when final Israeli body is returned
items.standfirst: Israel says it will reopen Gaza’s Rafah crossing once the body of the last Israeli captive held in Gaza is recovered.
items.content: Israel says it will reopen Gaza’s Rafah crossing once the body of the last Israeli captive held in Gaza is recovered.

clusters.title: Above the law? Outrage over ICE killings in Minneapolis
clusters.neutral_headline: Is the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown working

items.title: Above the law? Outrage over ICE killings in Minneapolis
items.standfirst: 17 days after the shooting death of Renée Good, masked Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in Minneapolis again shooting dead a US citizen, this time 37-year old Alex Pretti. Again, there's video evidence to contradict official narrative that the the victims were acting as domestic terrorists, the race to gather evidence before it can be tainted or destroyed, media echo chambers, and a US president who watches from on high.
items.content: 17 days after the shooting death of Renée Good, masked Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in Minneapolis again shooting dead a US citizen, this time 37-year old Alex Pretti. Again, there's video evidence to contradict official narrative that the the victims were acting as domestic terrorists, the race to gather evidence before it can be tainted or destroyed, media echo chambers, and a US president who watches from on high.

items.title: Latest details on federal hearings over Minnesota immigration operations
items.standfirst: Federal judges are hearing arguments Monday on two separate cases over the immigration crackdown in Minnesota. CBS News' Lana Zak has the latest.
items.content: Federal judges are hearing arguments Monday on two separate cases over the immigration crackdown in Minnesota. CBS News' Lana Zak has the latest.

items.title: White House takes questions about Border Patrol killing of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis
items.standfirst: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt answered questions Monday about Saturday's deadly Border Patrol shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis. CBS News' Willie James Inman and Anna Schecter have more.
items.content: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt answered questions Monday about Saturday's deadly Border Patrol shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis. CBS News' Willie James Inman and Anna Schecter have more.

items.title: Some Border Patrol agents in Alex Pretti shooting had body cams, officials confirm
items.standfirst: Two U.S. officials tell CBS News some of the Border Patrol agents involved in the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis had body cameras. Also on Monday, President Trump and Gov. Walz both confirmed they are in conversation about scaling down the federal surge in Minnesota.
items.content: Two U.S. officials tell CBS News some of the Border Patrol agents involved in the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis had body cameras. Also on Monday, President Trump and Gov. Walz both confirmed they are in conversation about scaling down the federal surge in Minnesota.

items.title: Walz says Trump considering reducing federal immigration enforcement forces in Minnesota
items.standfirst: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz says President Trump agreed to consider reducing federal immigration enforcement forces in Minnesota during a phone call on Monday morning. CBS News correspondent Lana Zak has the latest.
items.content: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz says President Trump agreed to consider reducing federal immigration enforcement forces in Minnesota during a phone call on Monday morning. CBS News correspondent Lana Zak has the latest.

items.title: Is the Trump administration’s immigration crackdown working?
items.standfirst: There has been a second fatal shooting in the US state of Minnesota this month.
items.content: There has been a second fatal shooting in the US state of Minnesota this month.

items.title: Ex-CBP commissioner says "wise to be very skeptical" of how Minneapolis shooting probe being handled
items.standfirst: Gil Kerlikowske, a former U.S. Customs and Border Patrol commissioner, said it's unprecedented for the federal government to exclude state and local officials from the investigation into Saturday's deadly shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis. "It's wise to be very skeptical of what's going on," Kerlikowske said.
items.content: Gil Kerlikowske, a former U.S. Customs and Border Patrol commissioner, said it's unprecedented for the federal government to exclude state and local officials from the investigation into Saturday's deadly shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis. "It's wise to be very skeptical of what's going on," Kerlikowske said.

items.title: Trump’s ICE crackdown faces reckoning as outrage mounts over Alex Pretti shooting
items.standfirst: President says his administration is reviewing fatal shooting as Republicans and Democrats criticize ICE surgeUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump’s efforts to deploy militarized immigration agents in US cities may finally be reaching a reckoning as he faces widespread opposition across the US, dissenting lawmakers in his own party, and impending court rulings after the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti by federal officers in Minneapolis.Trump said on Monday that his administration was reviewing the shooting of Pretti in Minneapolis by a federal officer, and that he would send border czar Tom Homan to Minnesota. Continue reading...
items.content: President says his administration is reviewing fatal shooting as Republicans and Democrats criticize ICE surgeUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump’s efforts to deploy militarized immigration agents in US cities may finally be reaching a reckoning as he faces widespread opposition across the US, dissenting lawmakers in his own party, and impending court rulings after the fatal shooting of Alex Pretti by federal officers in Minneapolis.Trump said on Monday that his administration was reviewing the shooting of Pretti in Minneapolis by a federal officer, and that he would send border czar Tom Homan to Minnesota. items.title: Schumer says Senate Democrats will block DHS funding bill after another deadly Minneapolis shooting
items.standfirst: Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said Senate Democrats will block the Homeland Security appropriations bill that's part of a government funding package after Border Patrol shot and killed 37-year-old Alex Pretti on Saturday. CBS News congressional correspondent Nikole Killion has more.

items.title: Trump dispatches border czar as judge weighs legality of ICE raids in Minnesota
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said Monday that border czar Tom Homan is heading to Minnesota as outrage mounts over the killing of US citizen Alex Pretti by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents. The move came as a federal judge began hearing arguments on whether the ICE crackdown in Minnesota violates the state's sovereignty and should be halted.
items.content: President Donald Trump said Monday that border czar Tom Homan is heading to Minnesota as outrage mounts over the killing of US citizen Alex Pretti by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents. The move came as a federal judge began hearing arguments on whether the ICE crackdown in Minnesota violates the state's sovereignty and should be halted.

items.title: US government shutdown looms as Democrats reject DHS funding over ICE issues
items.standfirst: A US government shutdown is increasingly likely as Democratic Senators refuse to approve the DHS funding bill, following the fatal shooting of a second US citizen by federal agents in Minneapolis. Key Democrats, including Chuck Schumer, Catherine Cortez Masto, and Patty Murray, demand changes to ICE operations before backing the bill. Without a resolution, the funding package could miss the January 31st deadline.
items.content: A US government shutdown is increasingly likely as Democratic Senators refuse to approve the DHS funding bill, following the fatal shooting of a second US citizen by federal agents in Minneapolis. Key Democrats, including Chuck Schumer, Catherine Cortez Masto, and Patty Murray, demand changes to ICE operations before backing the bill. Without a resolution, the funding package could miss the January 31st deadline.

clusters.title: A ferry carrying more than 350 people sinks off the Philippines, killing at least 18
clusters.neutral_headline: At least 18 people dead as Philippines ferry with 350 onboard sinks

items.title: A ferry carrying more than 350 people sinks off the Philippines, killing at least 18
At least 18 people dead as Philippines ferry with 350 onboard sinks
items.standfirst: Rescuers save at least 316 after inter-island ferry sank en route from city of Zamboanga to southern Jolo islandA ferry with more than 350 people onboard sank early on Monday near an island in the southern Philippines, killing at least 18 people, officials said. Rescuers saved hundreds more, while a fleet of coastguard and naval ships searched for those still missing.Coastguard officials said the cargo and passenger ferry apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight. The steel-hulled vessel abruptly tilted to one side and took on water, hurling people into the sea in the darkness, according to a rescued passenger who lost his six-month-old baby. Continue reading...
items.content: Rescuers save at least 316 after inter-island ferry sank en route from city of Zamboanga to southern Jolo islandA ferry with more than 350 people onboard sank early on Monday near an island in the southern Philippines, killing at least 18 people, officials said. Rescuers saved hundreds more, while a fleet of coastguard and naval ships searched for those still missing.Coastguard officials said the cargo and passenger ferry apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight. The steel-hulled vessel abruptly tilted to one side and took on water, hurling people into the sea in the darkness, according to a rescued passenger who lost his six-month-old baby. Continue reading...

items.title: Hundreds rescued after ferry capsizes in the Philippines
items.standfirst: At least 15 people were killed and more are missing after a ferry carrying more than 300 people capsized off the coast of the Philippines. The ferry was sailing with 332 passengers and 27 crew members when it apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight.
items.content: At least 15 people were killed and more are missing after a ferry carrying more than 300 people capsized off the coast of the Philippines. The ferry was sailing with 332 passengers and 27 crew members when it apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight.

items.content: At least 15 people have died after a ferry sank in the southern Philippines overnight.

items.title: Private jet crashes at Maine airport, killing 7 and seriously injuring 1
items.standfirst: The FAA says seven people were killed and a crew member survived with serious injuries when a business jet crashed in a snowstorm at Bangor International Airport.
items.content: The FAA says seven people were killed and a crew member survived with serious injuries when a business jet crashed in a snowstorm at Bangor International Airport.

items.title: Seven people killed in private plane crash in Maine, FAA says
items.standfirst: Seven people died, and one person was seriously injured, in a private jet crash on Sunday night in Bangor, Maine, the Federal Aviation Administration said. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul has more details.
items.content: Seven people died, and one person was seriously injured, in a private jet crash on Sunday night in Bangor, Maine, the Federal Aviation Administration said. CBS News' Shanelle Kaul has more details.

items.title: Seven killed and one injured in private jet crash in Maine during snowstorm
items.standfirst: Aircraft crashed at airport in Bangor, which has received about 10in of snow as deadly storm pummels USSeven people were killed and a crew member survived with serious injuries when a private business jet crashed in a snowstorm at Maine’s Bangor international airport, the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) says.The Bombardier Challenger 600 carrying eight people crashed on takeoff at about 7.45pm on Sunday night as Bangor, the rest of the New England region, and much of the country grappled with a deadly, massive winter storm. The airport, about 200 miles (320km) north of Boston, shut down after the crash. Continue reading...
items.content: Aircraft crashed at airport in Bangor, which has received about 10in of snow as deadly storm pummels USSeven people were killed and a crew member survived with serious injuries when a private business jet crashed in a snowstorm at Maine’s Bangor international airport, the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) says.The Bombardier Challenger 600 carrying eight people crashed on takeoff at about 7.45pm on Sunday night as Bangor, the rest of the New England region, and much of the country grappled with a deadly, massive winter storm. The airport, about 200 miles (320km) north of Boston, shut down after the crash. Continue reading...

items.title: Alex Honnold free solos Taipei 101 skyscraper in live Netflix climb
items.standfirst: US climber takes an hour and half to scale one of Asia’s tallest buildings without ropes or a harnessThe US rock climber Alex Honnold climbed one of Asia’s tallest skyscrapers without ropes or a harness on Sunday, fulfilling an ambition that began more than a decade ago and which he hoped would inspire people to pursue their own challenges because “time is finite”.Honnold, who starred in the 2019 Oscar-winning documentary Free Solo, ascended the 508-metre (1,667ft) Taipei 101 using the skyscraper’s horizontal metal beams to pull himself up with his bare hands. The challenge had originally been scheduled to take place on Saturday but was postponed because of rain. Continue reading...
items.content: US climber takes an hour and half to scale one of Asia’s tallest buildings without ropes or a harnessThe US rock climber Alex Honnold climbed one of Asia’s tallest skyscrapers without ropes or a harness on Sunday, fulfilling an ambition that began more than a decade ago and which he hoped would inspire people to pursue their own challenges because “time is finite”.Honnold, who starred in the 2019 Oscar-winning documentary Free Solo, ascended the 508-metre (1,667ft) Taipei 101 using the skyscraper’s horizontal metal beams to pull himself up with his bare hands. The challenge had originally been scheduled to take place on Saturday but was postponed because of rain. Continue reading...

items.title: Climber Alex Honnold scales Taipei 101 skyscraper without ropes
items.standfirst: American climber Alex Honnold ascended one of the world's tallest buildings on Sunday without a rope or protective equipment.
items.content: American climber Alex Honnold ascended one of the world's tallest buildings on Sunday without a rope or protective equipment.

clusters.title: Fate of China’s top general more likely to do with power struggle than corruption
clusters.neutral_headline: President Xi's purge is extraordinary - here's why

items.title: Fate of China’s top general more likely to do with power struggle than corruption
items.standfirst: Experts suggest Xi Jinping is asserting his authority by sidelining an officer who has significantly betrayed his trustStanding inches from Xi Jinping at a military ceremony in late December, China’s highest ranking general, Zhang Youxia, may have had little inkling about the fate that was to befall him just a few weeks later when he was put under investigation.The 75-year-old’s physical proximity to China’s leader, who stands to his right, reflects the position he holds in China’s hierarchy. As vice-chair of the Central Military Commission (CMC), the ruling body of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA), he is the second-most powerful person in China’s military, after Xi, the commander-in-chief. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts suggest Xi Jinping is asserting his authority by sidelining an officer who has significantly betrayed his trustStanding inches from Xi Jinping at a military ceremony in late December, China’s highest ranking general, Zhang Youxia, may have had little inkling about the fate that was to befall him just a few weeks later when he was put under investigation.The 75-year-old’s physical proximity to China’s leader, who stands to his right, reflects the position he holds in China’s hierarchy. As vice-chair of the Central Military Commission (CMC), the ruling body of the People’s Liberation Army (PLA), he is the second-most powerful person in China’s military, after Xi, the commander-in-chief. Continue reading...

items.title: President Xi's purge is extraordinary - here's why
items.standfirst: In a bombshell announcement, China's Ministry of Defence has said it is investigating General Zhang Youxia, China's most senior general and a man who was second only to Xi Jinping himself on China's top military decision-making body.
items.content: In a bombshell announcement, China's Ministry of Defence has said it is investigating General Zhang Youxia, China's most senior general and a man who was second only to Xi Jinping himself on China's top military decision-making body.

items.title: China’s top general under investigation for alleged violations amid corruption crackdown
items.standfirst: Zhang Youxia, long seen as Xi Jinping’s closest military ally, reportedly accused of leaking nuclear secrets to USChina’s military leadership is in turmoil after its most senior general – a close ally of Xi Jinping – was placed under investigation for “suspected serious violations of discipline and law”.Zhang Youxia is the joint vice-chairperson of the Central Military Commission (CMC), the ruling body of China’s People’s Liberation Army (PLA). Second only to Xi in the military command structure, Zhang has long been seen as the Chinese president’s closest military ally. Continue reading...
items.content: Zhang Youxia, long seen as Xi Jinping’s closest military ally, reportedly accused of leaking nuclear secrets to USChina’s military leadership is in turmoil after its most senior general – a close ally of Xi Jinping – was placed under investigation for “suspected serious violations of discipline and law”.Zhang Youxia is the joint vice-chairperson of the Central Military Commission (CMC), the ruling body of China’s People’s Liberation Army (PLA). Second only to Xi in the military command structure, Zhang has long been seen as the Chinese president’s closest military ally. Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: SEC drops lawsuit against Winklevoss twins’ crypto firm

items.title: SEC drops lawsuit against Winklevoss twins’ crypto firm
items.standfirst: Move comes as the SEC has taken a series of friendly stances towards the cryptocurrency industry under Trump The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Friday agreed to dismiss its enforcement case against a cryptocurrency exchange founded by billionaire twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss,…
items.content: Move comes as the SEC has taken a series of friendly stances towards the cryptocurrency industry under Trump The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Friday agreed to dismiss its enforcement case against a cryptocurrency exchange founded by billionaire twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss,…

items.title: SEC drops lawsuit against Winklevoss twins’ crypto firm
items.standfirst: Move comes as the SEC has taken a series of friendly stances towards the cryptocurrency industry under TrumpThe US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Friday agreed to dismiss its enforcement case against a cryptocurrency exchange founded by billionaire twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, after investors in its lending program recovered their assets in full.The SEC has taken a series of industry-friendly actions in recent years, a shift in its approach to crypto enforcement under Donald Trump, who promised to be the “crypto president”. He brought in more favorable rules and pledged to popularize mainstream use of digital currencies. Continue reading...
items.content: Move comes as the SEC has taken a series of friendly stances towards the cryptocurrency industry under TrumpThe US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) on Friday agreed to dismiss its enforcement case against a cryptocurrency exchange founded by billionaire twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, after investors in its lending program recovered their assets in full.The SEC has taken a series of industry-friendly actions in recent years, a shift in its approach to crypto enforcement under Donald Trump, who promised to be the “crypto president”. He brought in more favorable rules and pledged to popularize mainstream use of digital currencies. Continue reading...

items.title: UK supermarkets push for Amazon soy safeguards after Brazil scraps ban
items.standfirst: European retailers urge traders to adhere to commitments after Brazilian lawmakers drop forest protection agreement Leading British and European retailers are trying to salvage the core elements of the Amazon soy moratorium after the world’s most successful forest protection agreement was wrecked…
items.content: European retailers urge traders to adhere to commitments after Brazilian lawmakers drop forest protection agreement Leading British and European retailers are trying to salvage the core elements of the Amazon soy moratorium after the world’s most successful forest protection agreement was wrecked…

items.title: UK supermarkets push for Amazon soy safeguards after traders abandon ban
items.standfirst: European retailers urge traders to adhere to commitments after Brazilian lawmakers wreck forest protection pactLeading British and European retailers are trying to salvage the core elements of the Amazon soy moratorium after the world’s most successful forest protection agreement was wrecked by Brazilian lawmakers and abandoned by international traders.In an open letter, high street brands including Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Asda say the breakdown this month of the 20-year-old agreement will damage consumer confidence unless new arrangements are put in place to ensure grain production is not linked to deforestation. Continue reading...
items.content: European retailers urge traders to adhere to commitments after Brazilian lawmakers wreck forest protection pactLeading British and European retailers are trying to salvage the core elements of the Amazon soy moratorium after the world’s most successful forest protection agreement was wrecked by Brazilian lawmakers and abandoned by international traders.In an open letter, high street brands including Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Asda say the breakdown this month of the 20-year-old agreement will damage consumer confidence unless new arrangements are put in place to ensure grain production is not linked to deforestation. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Saudi satirist hacked with Pegasus spyware wins damages in court battle
clusters.neutral_headline: Saudi Arabia ordered to pay £3m to London dissident over Pegasus spying

items.title: Saudi satirist hacked with Pegasus spyware wins damages in court battle
items.standfirst: The London High Court awarded the London-based satirist and human rights activist Ghanem Al-Masarir more than £3 million, after finding the Saudi government hacked his phone and was likely behind a physical attack targeting him in London.
items.content: The London High Court awarded the London-based satirist and human rights activist Ghanem Al-Masarir more than £3 million, after finding the Saudi government hacked his phone and was likely behind a physical attack targeting him in London.

items.title: Saudi Arabia ordered to pay £3m to London dissident over Pegasus spying
items.standfirst: High court finds kingdom responsible for hacking phones of Ghanem al-Masarir and for physical attack on himA judge has ordered Saudi Arabia to pay more than £3m in damages to a London-based dissident whose phones were targeted with Pegasus spyware.In a judgment handed down on Monday, Judge Pushpinder Saini ruled that Ghanem al-Masarir was entitled to compensation for psychiatric harm sustained after discovering that his iPhones had been hacked, as well as a physical attack on him outside Harrods in central London. Continue reading...
items.content: High court finds kingdom responsible for hacking phones of Ghanem al-Masarir and for physical attack on himA judge has ordered Saudi Arabia to pay more than £3m in damages to a London-based dissident whose phones were targeted with Pegasus spyware.In a judgment handed down on Monday, Judge Pushpinder Saini ruled that Ghanem al-Masarir was entitled to compensation for psychiatric harm sustained after discovering that his iPhones had been hacked, as well as a physical attack on him outside Harrods in central London. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Syria peace deal at risk as government forces and Kurdish fighters accuse each other of violations
clusters.neutral_headline: Syrian army, Kurdish-led SDF accuse each other of ceasefire violations

items.title: Syria peace deal at risk as government forces and Kurdish fighters accuse each other of violations
items.standfirst: Since the January 18th peace deal, Syrian government forces and Kurdish-led SDF have accused each other of violating the ceasefire. The government opened humanitarian corridors and released some prisoners, while many Kurdish families returned home. Despite this, tensions remain, with both sides accusing each other of violations, and the truce is considered fragile. Sunni families in Raqqa are also waiting for news on relatives held in government prisons.
items.content: Since the January 18th peace deal, Syrian government forces and Kurdish-led SDF have accused each other of violating the ceasefire. The government opened humanitarian corridors and released some prisoners, while many Kurdish families returned home. Despite this, tensions remain, with both sides accusing each other of violations, and the truce is considered fragile. Sunni families in Raqqa are also waiting for news on relatives held in government prisons.

items.title: Syrian army, Kurdish-led SDF accuse each other of ceasefire violations
